title: fs::read_to_string panic when reading from sysfs file
body:
I tried this code: ```rust let status_path = charger_path.path().join(POWER_SUPPLY_STATUS); if !status_path.exists() { continue; } let status_string = read_to_string(&status_path) .with_context(|| format!("Error reading status from {}", status_path.display()))?; ``` From https://source.chromium.org/chromiumos/chromiumos/codesearch/+/main:src/platform2/resourced/src/power.rs;l=103 The code reads a `status` entry in `sysfs`. I suspect this `sysfs` entry doesn't have the `lseek` syscall implemented. I expected to see this happen: I expected a failure result to be returned by `read_to_string` because lseek returned an error. Instead, this happened: The processes panicked The backtrace I have is from a running system that threw a coredump. I suspect it's because we are running in a [loop](https://stdrs.dev/nightly/x86_64-unknown-linux-gnu/src/std/io/mod.rs.html#372) and we overflowed the buffer, so we need to increase the buffer size, rewind the file and then read again. I don't know the exact contents of the sysfs file nor do I have a local repro case yet. ### Meta `rustc --version --verbose`: ``` $ rustc --version --verbose rustc 1.58.1-nightly (rust-host-1.58.1-r1) binary: rustc commit-hash: unknown commit-date: unknown host: x86_64-unknown-linux-gnu release: 1.58.1-nightly LLVM version: 13.0.0 ```
